p.span: This is a challenging time for our school community as we all enter uncharted territory and work to balance careers, families and childcare needs. Aristoi is taking every precaution available to keep our faculty, staff, and students safe. The Administration is in constant contact with the Texas Education Agency (TEA) and the Texas Public Charter Schools Association (TPSCA), and is following the CDC guidelines. With this in mind, Aristoi will be closed through May 4th.
Please utilize our new email for all COVID-19 related questions: coronavirus@aristoiclassical.org

Aristoi Classical Academy supports our parents' decisions regarding their child's well-being and attendance at school. If your child was absent prior to Spring Break and you believe it was related to COVID-19, please contact Aristoi's Attendance Clerk, Mrs. Garza, to discuss your child’s absence.

p.strong: Q. When does online learning begin?

div.div: A. Google Classrooms and online learning launch March 23. More information and emails will be sent from the Administration and individual teachers. Please continue to check emails and the website for details.

p.strong: Q. What if students do not have textbooks and materials at home?

div.span: A. All necessary materials will be available online and from the teacher's in the Google Classroom sites.

p.strong: Q. What if my student doesn’t finish the work in the recommended amount of time?

span.style: font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial; color: #000000; background-color: transparent; font-weight: 400; font-variant: normal; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap

div.span: A. Each teacher is establishing these parameters. Please contact your student’s teacher if you need additional support and advice.

p.strong: Q. What if I cannot help my student with their work?

div.div: A. Teachers are available Monday-Friday to answer emails from students and parents.

p.strong: Q. What if my student needs accommodations, how will that work?

span.style: font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial; color: #000000; background-color: transparent; font-weight: 400; font-variant: normal; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap

span.span: ur Special Education team is working to ensure that all accommodations and modifications are included for students.

p.strong: Q. Are there other resources we can use?

span.style: font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial; color: #404040; background-color: transparent; font-weight: 400; font-variant: normal; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap

div.span: A. In their websites and Google Classrooms, many teachers are including resources such as Khan Academy, Discovery Education, Imagine Math, and a host of other links and websites to enrich the students’ experiences.

p.strong: Q. May students collaborate with classmates?

div.div: A. Yes. Students may be in contact with classmates by phone or computer (please do not gather in-person). Working with other students, especially Upper School students, may prove helpful and beneficial. However, please remember that students must submit their own work. Academic honesty and plagiarism rules still apply.

p.strong: Q. How much time will I need to schedule to work with my children?

span.style: font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial; color: #404040; background-color: transparent; font-weight: 400; font-variant: normal; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap

div.span: A. The amount of help each student needs depends on the student and subject matter. Upper School students should be able to work more independently than Elementary School students. The transition to online schooling may take a brief adjustment period and extra time to work through Google Classroom, but once that habit is established, signing in and launching lessons should work easily.

p.strong: Q. How will my student's work be graded?

span.style: font-size: 12pt; font-family: Arial; color: #000000; background-color: transparent; font-weight: 400; font-variant: normal; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap

div.span: A. Some of the student’s work will be graded for completion. Other materials will be evaluated for quality and correctness. As a parent, you will not be required to grade anything, but you may be asked to sign off on certain tasks (e.g. reading for a certain amount of time very day).

p.strong: Q. What happens after May 4?

span.style: font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial; color: #404040; background-color: transparent; font-weight: 400; font-variant: normal; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap
span.span: A. The Aristoi leadership team is constantly monitoring the COVID-19 situation with the help and guidance of the Governor, TEA, and TPCSA. Any changes will be made in accordance with these governing bodies.

p.strong: Q. Will I, or my student, be able to access the school campuses?

div.span: A. The schools are temporarily closed to parents and students. Access to lockers, the campuses, or facilities is not available at this time.

p.strong: Q. Has Aristoi had a confirmed case of COVID-19?

div.div: A. There are no confirmed cases at this time.

p.strong: Q. How will I be updated of changes or developments?

div.div: A. Please continue to check the Aristoi website for news and announcements. All communications are shared via email, the website, and the Aristoi-supported facebook page (Aristoi Classical Academy).

p.strong: Q. May I pick up my student's medicine from Student Care?

div.div: A. ONLY parents may pick up medicine from the Upper School and Elementary School Student Care Offices. Parents must not be ill, must be symptom free, and must not have traveled outside of the US for the past two months. Only one parent will be allowed in the building; children and students will not be allowed within the offices. Disinfecting protocols will take place upon entry and exit of the buildings.
Appointments must made with the Upper School - asarver@aristoiclassical.org and Elementary School - jsmock@aristoiclassical.org

p.strong: Q. How will an extended school closure impact my child's attendance? How does this impact the required time of instruction?

div.div: A. We are also working with TEA, TPCSA, and the Governor's office for additional information. You can read more here: https://tea.texas.gov/, https://txcharterschools.org/covid19/

p.strong: Q. Will there be a graduation ceremony for the seniors?

div.div: A. Graduation is currently schedule for May 23rd. If changes need to be made, we will address those concerns when necessary.

p.strong: Q. What about the scheduled theatre, band, and choir productions?

div.div: A. All events have been cancelled through May 4th.

p.strong: Q. What about STAAR testing?

div.div: A. STAAR testing has been waived for the academic year 2019-2020. Please see https://tea.texas.gov/about-tea/news-and-multimedia/correspondence/taa-letters/cancellation-of-staar-testing-for-the-remainder-of-the-school-year

p.strong: Q. Are meal services available?

div.div: A. To assist families in meeting the needs of students during the district closure, school breakfast and lunches will be offered to all Katy area children ages 0-18, free of charge. Children do not need to be an enrolled in a Katy ISD school in order to receive a meal. The meals will be served at the campuses listed below from 9:00 a.m. - 11:30 a.m. Monday through Friday, beginning on Monday, March 16, 2020. All meals will be provided in a "grab and go" style outside of the cafeteria near the covered walkway where buses pickup and drop off students. Families will not be able to enter the campus during the meal service.

p.strong: Q. How do I prevent the spread of COVID-19?

div.div: A. Please monitor the CDC and WHO websites for detailed information. There is great information here from the CDC.

p.strong: Q. What is COVID-19?

div.div: A. Coronaviruses are a large family of viruses. Some cause illness in people, and others, such as canine and feline coronaviruses, only infect animals. Rarely, animal coronaviruses that infect animals have emerged to infect people and can spread between people. This is suspected to have occurred for the virus that causes COVID-19. Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) are two other examples of coronaviruses that originated from animals and then spread to people. More information about the source and spread of COVID-19 is available on the Situation Summary: Source and Spread of the Virus. (From the CDC).
